Posts.Content: Congratulations Scriptfan.  Little ones have such a way about them and the best bit is you have the right to spoil them as much as you want  Quick question - I had 1st EC nearly 3 weeks ago.  I cold capped but over the last few days my scalp has been getting more uncomfortable (like I've had my hair in a tight ponytail - I haven't as I had it all cut off before I started!)   I am presuming that I am going to lose some or all, so I'm wondering how long after it starts hurting it might start coming out and did u lose all of it or just the bits that hurt?
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Watermelon works well for itchy rashs.  I can't tell you if it will work for this but it does take the bite out of eczema, heat rash etc so it may work.  Just rub on and leave to soak in.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Well no 2 didn't quite go to plan.   Change of anti sickness meds and no cooling cap meant no headache, but first night involved 10 hours of vomiting and being unable to keep anything including water down, before an overnight stay in Hotel NHS to hydrate and investigate possible infection. After 4 doses of antibiotics, they decided I didn't and could go home but although I'm on day 5 I've been left feeling absolutely rubbish, still a bit queasy, very burpy and a weird sensation in my oesphagus/stomach like heartburn but isn't.   And now I have the fun of the injections too so here comes the bad back.  I'm ready to feel better now
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Fantastic new Script Fan. I'm off for round 2 today.  Bloods are ok, change of anti sickness meds as they think that's what caused the horrendous headache, but Still got to decide on the cooling cap (hair is shedding lots!)  Looking forward to a few days of rough (not) but hopefully on the up for Xmas.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi. Sorry you find yourself here. I also have 2 kids about the same ages as yours and had my first chemo yesterday.  I won't lie I felt rather rough last night (but had arranged for kids to have a sleep over so I had some peace) but today bit nauseous but mainly tired.  I cold capped to try to save my hair, they were right when they told me that the first 15-20 mins are the worst then you get used to it.  It does extend your treatment time drastically but to me worth a go. I have been quite honest with my kids, they know mummy has cancer and that the doctors need to give me some medicine that could make me poorly.  They need to be helpful and not too noisy if I'm not well and that mummy might lose her hair.  I took my daughter (shes 8) with me to buy a new hat and they are both coping remarkably well.  My daughter got upset when I first told her as she said she didnt want me to be bald like daddy! You are strong and amazing and just need to take one day at a time.  Just remember this is all to ensure you can spend many many years and decades with those special monkeys.
Posts.Title: How to cope

Posts.Content: Hi MicheyW We sound like we are on a similar path, I'm in my 30s and a few months ago I was diagnosed with stage 4
Posts.Title: new member stage 4 breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi MicheyW We sound like we are on a similar path, I'm in my 30s and a few months ago I was diagnosed with stage 4 breast cancer that has spread to my lymph nodes.  I still find it hard at times, other than a lump I had no symptoms and the lump appeared very quickly and very big.  I was shocked to be told I had cancer and then was a bitter blow to find it was already out.M My treatment is Zoladex to inhibit my ovaries (I'm going to have them removed later in the year) and letrozole for the rest of the oestrogen and Palbociclib (targeted treatment similar to chemo) to attack the cancer.  Overall, it's not too bad.  Only been on it for a month and fatigue is creeping in but that's mainly because I haven't got used to adjusting and my new way of life. Hope you are doing ok and staying positive.  I think that's half the battle. if you want to chat then happy too
Posts.Title: new member stage 4 breast cancer

Posts.Content: Sorry for the first post, it went a bit funny!! You have to just take some time to process it all, have some you time, listen to what your body is saying and enjoy every day.  I try not to look too far ahead and have chosen that I am going to ignore any information they have given me about timescales etc. I am not ready to go anywhere and am going to be the exception.  They can't get rid of me that easily.   Sorry you are having to go through this though and sending you hugs as it really is a horrible time xx
Posts.Title: new member stage 4 breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi. Sorry you find yourself here. I also have 2 kids about the same ages as yours and had my first chemo yesterday.  I won't lie I felt rather rough last night (but had arranged for kids to have a sleep over so I had some peace) but today bit nauseous but mainly tired.  I cold capped to try to save my hair, they were right when they told me that the first 15-20 mins are the worst then you get used to it.  It does extend your treatment time drastically but to me worth a go. I have been quite honest with my kids, they know mummy has cancer and that the doctors need to give me some medicine that could make me poorly.  They need to be helpful and not too noisy if I'm not well and that mummy might lose her hair.  I took my daughter (shes 8) with me to buy a new hat and they are both coping remarkably well.  My daughter got upset when I first told her as she said she didnt want me to be bald like daddy! You are strong and amazing and just need to take one day at a time.  Just remember this is all to ensure you can spend many many years and decades with those special monkeys.
Posts.Title: How to cope

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your wife is going through all this on top of the cancer.  Sickness and nausea is not nice at any time.  While I don't have experience of this, I was very sick on EC - ended up admitted to hospital but then changed chemos and it hasn't been an issue really since. I was told that peppermint is very good for nausea and is very settling and gentle for the stomach.  I now drink peppermint tea during the day - it is good for fluids and gentle for you. Hope you manage to get it sorted xx
Posts.Title: Sickness weeks after chemo course

Posts.Content: Hi.  Does anyone have any experience with 5FU?  They've recommended it to my dad and they've said its over a 2 week period - 3 days treatment 11 days off.   Could anyone tell me how affected they were, is he going to be able to do stuff during the 11 days or if he going to be wiped out. He really wants to be able to do things over the summer, but we arent sure what to expect or if we can plan anything. Thanks
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Funny how it is all different, I am was also told to not take my temperature unless I felt ill.
Posts.Title: Temperature

Posts.Content: I got mine in lidl think it was £8.99.  It does ear or forehead in about 3 secs
Posts.Title: Temperature

Posts.Content: I saw this as a post on Facebook and summed it up for me!! When you can't control what's happening, challenge yourself to control the way you respond to what it happening.   That is where your power is.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: I can relate to this post. I've been on letrozole for 6 months and have no interest in anything sexual.  Not only too tired but no desire and not that comfortable if we do.  Emotions I may have suppressed while I try and get my head around all this cancer cr*p.  Life really can be quite rubbish sometimes. And to think that this is my life now and I will be on them forever.... its odd as it doesn't bother me too much but feel for my husband.  Just something else he will have to get used to.  This B.C. malarkey is robbing us of so much.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else feel totally emotionless taking Letrozole?

Posts.Content: So Paclitaxol has now stopped working again.  This silly cancer is seeming to be a bit too intelligent for my liking and the inflammatory has flared back up. So does anyone have any experience of Eribulin? Starting on Weds.
Posts.Title: **MAY 2019 BREAST CANCER CHEMOTHERAPY CHAT**

Posts.Content: Hi. Sorry to find you hear, I can imagine you would be beside yourself with worry. When they were concerned about a lesion on my liver after my initial ct, they sent me for a PET scan.  I was told it can give them a better idea if areas are cancerous as the area takes up the radio active glucose.  I was lucky, it didn't take it up but unfortunately a couple of lymph nodes did. Hope they manage to work it out and sending you a big hug in case you need it x
Posts.Title: Modules on the lung
